title-group.article-title: Analysis of cardiopulmonary bypass status in China: eight-year development trends

contrib-group.aff: Department of Cardiopulmonary Bypass, Cardiovascular Institute & Fuwai Heart Hospital, PUMC & CAMS, Beijing, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Cun Long, Department of Cardiopulmonary Bypass, Fuwai Hospital National Center for Cardiovascular Diseases, Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences and Peking Union Medical College 167 Beilishi Road XichengQu, Beijing, 100037 People’s Republic of China Email: fuwaicpb@mx.cei.gov.cn

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: To study the development of cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) in the past 8 years and to come up with predictions and recommendations for the future in China.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Domestic hospitals performing cardiovascular operations were supplied with questionnaires, annually (between 2003 and 2008), upon the number of on-pump and off-pump cardiovascular operations, oxygenators of different types and the number of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO). All the hospitals in this study were divided into 8 grades, according to the number of cardiovascular operations. The market share of hospitals in each grade was analyzed.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The total anumber of cardiovascular operations was 170,547 in 2010, of which 136,753 were performed under CPB. The ratio of imported membrane oxygenators increased from 43.22% in 2003 to 59.75% in 2010, while bubble oxygenator composition decreased from 43.78% in 2003 to 14.59% in 2010. Forty-four hospitals carried out 206 cases of ECMO in 2010. There were 32 hospitals that performed cardiovascular operations of over 1,000 cases and their market share was 43%. There were 255 hospitals that performed cardiovascular operations in less than 50 cases and their market share was only 3%.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: CPB in China has gone through a rapid development in the past eight years. Medical resources for CPB should be concentrated and systematic training regulations should be established in the future.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In the past several decades, cardiovascular disease has been one of the main reasons for the death rate in China. Presently, about 230 million people suffer from cardiovascular diseases in China and about 3 million people die of cardiovascular diseases annually.1 Cardiovascular operation under cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) is the most commonly used way to treat cardiovascular diseases such as coronary atherosclerotic heart disease, rheumatic valvular heart disease and congenital heart disease, etc. Each year, about 8 million patients should receive cardiovascular operations in China2 and more operations are expected to be performed in the future. Furthermore, the great improvement in cardiovascular operation techniques, such as heart transplants, brings more hope to patients with critical cardiovascular conditions. Thus, the development of CPB is necessary to meet the increasing demand and to tackle the difficulty of cardiovascular operations. The study of Chinese hospitals which performed CPB and cardiovascular operations from 2003 to 2010 provides us with, not just a review of the development, but rather an overview of CPB enterprise in the future in China.

sec.title: Target group
sec.p: Chinese hospitals which performed CPB and cardiovascular operations from 2003 to 2010, as well as perfusionists applying for membership of the Chinese Society of Extracorporeal Circulation in 2005, were studied. All the hospitals which performed CPB and cardiovascular operations were identified through the Chinese Society of Extracorporeal Circulation. Investigators were able to approach all hospitals and follow up on non-responders by telephone.

sec.title: Study methodology
sec.p: Each year, questionnaires were sent to hospitals which performed CPB and cardiovascular operations. The study contents, response ratio and detailed data are listed in Table 1. Contents of this study include the number of cardiovascular operations, the number of CPBs, application details of oxygenators and the condition of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: Statistical analysis was conducted using MS excel 2007 (http://Microsoftstore.com) as follows: annual constitutions of cardiopulmonary operations on-pump and off-pump; application details of imported membrane oxygenators, domestic membrane oxygenators and domestic bubble oxygenators; the constitution of perfusionists countrywide in 2005.

According to the number of cardiovascular operations, hospitals in this research were divided into 8 grades: above 1000 cases, 800-1000cases, 600-800 cases, 400-600 cases, 200-400 cases, 100-200 cases, 50-100 cases and less than 50 cases. The market share of the hospitals in each grade were calculated for the year 2003 and the year 2010 (the market share of the hospitals in each grade = the number of operations in each grade ÷ the total anumber of operations countrywide).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The total number of cardiovascular operations gradually increased to 170,547 in 2010 from 76,319 in 2003. Among them, 136,753 in 2010 and 59,886 in 2003 were on-pump. The ratio of on-pump operations increased from 2003 to 2007 while they decreased from 2007 to 2010. All the details are shown in Figure 1.

caption.p: The change in cardiovascular operations on-pump and off-pump from 2003 to 2010.

sec.p: As a result of the increasing number of cardiovascular operations, the use of oxygenators went up gradually to 137,670 in 2010 from 73,134 in 2004. The usage ratio of imported membrane oxygenators increased from 43.22% in 2004 to 59.75% in 2010 and the usage ratio of domestic membrane oxygenators increased from 13% in 2004 to 25.66% in 2010, while the usage ratio of domestic bubble oxygenators decreased from 43.78% in 2004 to 14.59% in 2010. All the details are shown in Figure 2.

caption.p: The condition of oxygenators used in China from 2004 to 2010.

sec.p: Only 11 of the hospitals performed over 1,000 cases of cardiovascular operations in 20033 and their market share was 28%. Most of the hospitals were in the grades of 50 to 100 cases (104 hospitals) and less than 50 cases (172 hospitals) and the market shares were 10% and 6%, respectively. The number of hospitals that performed over 1,000 cases of cardiovascular operations increased to 32 in 2010; this is equivalent to 43% of the total number of operations performed. There were 255 hospitals that performed less than 50 cases in 2010 and this represented only about 3% of the total operations performed. All the details are shown in Figure 3 and Figure 4.

caption.p: Hospitals in different grades according to the number of cardiovascular operations in the years 2003 and 2010.
Market share for hospitals in the different grades in the years 2003 and 2010.

sec.p: More and more hospitals carried out ECMO and cases of ECMO have increased gradually since 2004. The number of hospitals that carried out ECMO in 2010 is double that of 2004 and cases of ECMO in 2010 were 2.5 times more than in 2004. All the details are shown in Figure 5.

caption.p: Hospitals which carried out ECMO and their case numbers from 2004 to 2010.

sec.p: Fuwai Cardiovascular Hospital holds the No.1 position in both the number of cardiovascular operations (4915 operations in 2003, 7007 operations in 2007 and 9384 operations in 2010) and the number of CPB cases (3931 cases in 2003, 5900 cases in 2007 and 7394 cases in 2010) in China for the past 8 years. Other hospitals, such as Anzhen Hospital and Xijing Hospital are also among the first grade which performed over 1000 cardiovascular operation cases annually.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In our opinion, the development of CPB is crucial to the development of cardiovascular surgery to meet the increasing demands of cardiovascular operations. CPB has advanced quite a bit in the past few years, dealing with patients with serious and complicated cardiovascular conditions, including heart transplantation operations. Nonetheless, CPB is a new topic, with a history of only several decades in China. It still has a lot of potential and has a long way to go. Therefore, it is very important to analyze the development, find out the challenges and to come up with constructive suggestions on CPB in China.

Both the number of cardiovascular operations and the number of operations with CPB increased significantly in China in the past 8 years. About 171,000 cardiovascular operations and about 138,000 cases with CPB were performed in 2010. The ratio of operations on-pump increased from 2003 to 2007 and reached the highest point at 83.42% in 2007. However, it decreased from 2007 to 2010 and reached 80.18% in 2010. This may be the result of the increase in off-pump coronary artery bypasses performed in the past 3 years. However, an article on the long-term follow-up results4 revealed that the chances of stroke, hospital re-admission, and cerebrovascular events in patients who received cardiovascular operations off-pump are higher than those receiving operations on-pump. So we predict that cardiovascular operations on-pump will be more important than operations off-pump in future. This also indicates that there is a lot of potential for the development of CPB in China.

As far as oxygenators were concerned, imported membrane oxygenators were mostly used and the usage ratio increased gradually. On the other hand, the usage ratio of bubble oxygenators decreased significantly because of their disadvantages, such as large priming volume, blood destruction, etc. Though membrane oxygenators are more expensive than bubble oxygenators, they have many advantages, such as a reduction in the priming volume, less blood destruction, improvement of the quality of CPB in long perfusions, an increase in the success ratio of cardiovascular operations, a reduction in complications post-operation, etc.5-9 These advantages were even more outstanding with the use of heparin-coated techniques in the CPB setting.10 On the other hand, more and more Chinese people became richer in recent years. So, we predict that membrane oxygenators will be used prevalently and bubble oxygenators will gradually be eliminated through selection or competition in China. Furthermore, the usage ratio of domestic membrane oxygenators increased significantly due to the improvements in design, materials and performance. With the pricing competitiveness, domestic membrane oxygenators will be able expand their market share in the future.

There is a gradual increase in both the number of hospitals capable of performing cardiovascular operations and the number of operations performed by each hospital in recent years. Although the number of hospitals which performed over 1,000 cases of cardiovascular operations was three times as that of 2003, most of the other hospitals (529 hospitals) performed fewer than 200 operations annually, among which 255 hospitals performed fewer than 50 cases. As far as the market share was concerned, hospitals that performed over 1000 cases annually owned the biggest market share and their market share increased gradually to 43% in 2010, while the market share of 255 hospitals that performed less than 50 cases annually decreased gradually to 3% in 2010. This situation indicates that many new hospitals carried out cardiovascular operations and all these hospitals should improve the quality of the surgery. Moreover, the resources of cardiovascular patients should be more effectively leveraged. The development of cardiovascular surgery and CPB relies on accumulating experience through practice. It may be a waste in resources for hospitals that performed fewer than 100 operations annually, let alone gain enough experience to achieve expected improvements. Therefore, we suggest that resources on cardiovascular surgery and CPB in China should be concentrated so as to improve the countrywide level quickly in the future.

Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) is a new cardiopulmonary support technique that may save patients with severe heart failure or respiratory failure. ECMO was introduced into China in 2004. Hospitals that carried out ECMO and cases of ECMO increased significantly during the past 7 years. ECMO brings Chinese CPB enterprise into a new field, including the improved expertise of perfusionists and an improvement of CPB locations. It is worth mentioning that ECMO helped save quite a number patients with flu of the H1N1 type in 2009.

The prospect of CPB in China is very promising because of the advancement in cardiovascular surgery techniques. Heart transplantation techniques have improved gradually and cases of CPB increase significantly. In this study, both progress and problems pertaining to CPB in China have been revealed. It is believed that progress in future can be made by concentrating resources on cardiovascular surgery and CPB, providing professional training to perfusionists and strengthening the cooperation of cardiovascular surgery teams.
